doc.after: The Enciclopedia universal ilustrada europeo-americana (also called Enciclopedia Espasa, or Enciclopedia Espasa-Calpe, after its publisher) is a Spanish encyclopedia comprising 72 volumes (numbered from 1 to 70, with parts 18 and 28 consisting of two volumes each) published from 1908 to 1930 plus a ten-volume appendix published 1930â33. Between 1935 and 2003, 33 supplemental volumes were published plus an index, another AâZ appendix, and an atlas, for a total of 118 volumes. Each of the volumes vary in length. It is currently the longest[1] printed encyclopedia with 105,000 pages and 165,200,000 words as of 1986[update].
